text:
DON TOMASKOVIC-DEVEY:
Good afternoon.
My name's Don Tomaskovic-Devey.

I'm at University of
Massachusetts Amherst.

I see there's a lot of
old friends in the room,

and people I cite and whose
research I really value.

And I hope to
start relationships

with a new group
of people today.

So I'm going to tell
you a little bit about--

it's an advertisement
for a new center,

but it's also a conceptual
notion of what works
and an intervention.

I spent most of my career
as a conventional academic,

publishing conventional
academic things.

But I've had a second life
working with the US Equal

Employment Opportunity
Commission,

which I find sometimes hopeful
and many times really, really
frustrating.
And so that's the background.

So the center here
has been created

by Lee Badgett,
and Fidan Kurtulus,

who are both in economics at
UMass Amherst, and myself,

after basically about
five years of trying

to change the way
the EEOC did its work

and thought about
academic research.

And in some ways
we've been successful.

I won't tell you too
much about that now.

If you're interested,
come and ask me.

But one of the things we
did is create enough trust

that we now actually have
access to their data.

And what the center
is trying to do

is build both the research
proposal portfolio

and, this is what I want
to talk about today,

a public-facing portfolio
leveraging that relationship.
So in general, we've got as a--

this is reflects
that frustration.

An argument that we need to
move away from legal compliance

approaches to
diversity and bias,

and towards thinking about these
as organizational processes
and managerial responsibilities.

Now, I've heard a lot
of this in the room.

But if even think about the last
conversation that we just had,

there was a legal compliance
versus managerial tension
in there.

And so we're trying to
do this both through

the scientific route and then
democratize what's going on.

And I'm going to give you just
a high level, medium level,
and low level example.

So there's a website and
we've got data up there,

that you might be
very interested in,
and some reports.

So the first
argument we're making

is that if you're going to
worry about diversity or bias

as a manager, you're going
to do it the way managers do
everything else.

You're going to
count and compare.

You're going to think
about outcomes and not
just processes.

The common equal
opportunity practices
look something like this.

We set some goals, we think
about practices or processes,

and then we get to legal
compliance or self-satisfied,

OK, we've done all that
we're supposed to do.

And this is not how real
managerial practices normally
work.

And how things
normally work is you've

got a product or
profit, something
that you're trying to do.

You evaluate it, you
adjust the process,
and then you come back.

And so that is, you have to
account outcomes, not just
processes.

And if you're not
counting the outcomes,

if you're not
worrying about, oh,

how many sexual
harassment complaints am
I getting in this firm?
And is it enough?
Or what are the responses?

Or what is my turnover
look like specifically

in comparing various groups,
then you're not managing it.
So that's the argument.

So one of the things
we're trying to--
that's a high level argument.

But we also think there's
some simple methodologies.

This is the Department
of Energy over--

that which is the federal
department of energy.

This is the gender
wage gap over time.
You can see there's good news.
It's going down.

But we can also say
where it's coming from.

Is it because the
Department of Energy

hires men and women
with different skills?

Is it because they
segregate them.

Or is it something that happens
face to face in the same job?

These, from a scientific
point of view,

are really easy
models to estimate.

Any employer could do
this for themselves.

We also want to
emphasize that it's not

only this self-analysis
that's possible,
but there's comparison.

Silicon Valley tech firms have
been under a lot of pressure

around diversity issues,
around gender, and around race.

In such a way that sometimes
it seems impossible.

This is like a place where
it's hard to move the needle.

So one of the things that we
did is we just compared the 200
largest Silicon Valley firms.

It turns out there
were some that

are much worse than the
average, which is pretty bad.

But it also show
it also turns out

there are some that
are quite better.

And so we can be
thinking about that.

There's internal models
of successful firms.

And then last,
like everyone else,

we'll talk about sexual
harassment for a moment.

So as I walk away, the
key thing-- takeaway

on sexual harassment is
the EEOC actually treats it

more seriously than other
forms of segregation.

And the employers
are extraordinarily

harsh with women who make
sexual harassment charges.
That's the data.
[APPLAUSE]
